summary.p: The Jñānārṇava is a Digambara Jain text on dhyāna (meditation, contemplation) by Śubhacandra, tentatively placed in the 11th century. The text, in 39 chapters, deals with four kinds of dhyāna, which Paul Dundas considers to be an influence from Kashmiri Śaivism (2002, 169).

This manuscript contains the first 12 chapters. It was perhaps originally a longer manuscript, but, on the last folio, the beginning of the 13th chapter has been deleted with yellow paste, in order to create the semblance of a complete manuscript.
There are also some intertextual comments, in red ink, which act as a very basic commentary. For example, verse 1.14 is preceded by anya ca, and verse 1.21 is preceded by kiṃ ca (2r).

msItem.author: Śubhacandra
msItem.incipit:
jñānalakṣmīghanāśleṣaprabhavānaṃdanaṃditaṃ | niṣṭhitārtham ajaṃ naimi | paramātmāna
m avyayaṃ || 1 ||
msItem.explicit:
nirvinnair bhavasaṃkramāc chrutadharair ekāṃtato nispṛhaiḥ | nāryā vya
dy api ṇiṃditāḥ śamadhanair brahmavratālaṃbibhiḥ | niṃdyaṃte na tathāpi ṇirmmalayam asvādhyāyavṛttāṃki
tā nirvedapraśamādipuṇyacaritaiḥr yāḥ śuddhibhūtā bhuvaḥ || 58 ||
msItem.finalRubric:
iti jñānārṇave jogapradīpādhikāre ācāryaśrī
śubhacaṃdradevaviracite strīsvarūpapratipādanaṃ dvādaśodhyāẏa || 12 ||

layoutDesc.layout: Quadruple margin lines on the left and right. Ruling for the śirorekha on the top line of each folio.

handNote.desc: Dental na and retroflex ṇa often interchanged.
